C.elegans plate experiment setup # libraries library(here) ## here() starts at /Users/naresh/Documents/08_DSFB/DSFB2_portfolio library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ── ## ✔ dplyr 1.1.4 ✔ readr 2.1.5 ## ✔ forcats 1.0.0 ✔ stringr 1.5.1 ## ✔ ggplot2 3.4.4 ✔ tibble 3.2.1 ## ✔ lubridate 1.9.3 ✔ tidyr 1.3.1 ## ✔ purrr 1.0.2 ## ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ## ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() ## ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors library(readxl) library(ggplot2) library(reactable) Import and inspect dataset # import C.elegans data file CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata <- read_excel( here::here( "raw_data", "CE.LIQ.FLOW.062_Tidydata.xlsx")) # inspecting data in table format with the reactable reactable(data = CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata, defaultPageSize = 5, compact = T, highlight = T) Scatterplot Pseudocode Decide which columns will be included in the scatterplot Checking and if needed change the datatypes of columns Plot the data in a scatterplot using ggplot Normalise y-axis counts Set the x-axis to a log10 scale Use Jitter to avoid overlaps of points # inspect the type of data of column RawData, compName, and compConcentration CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata %>% select( RawData, compName, compConcentration, expType) %>% map(class) ## $RawData ## [1] "numeric" ## ## $compName ## [1] "character" ## ## $compConcentration ## [1] "character" ## ## $expType ## [1] "character" # Change "compConcentration" to numeric CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$compConcentration <- parse_number(CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$compConcentration) # change "compName" into a factor CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$compName <- factor(CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$compName, levels = unique(CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$compName)) # change "expType" into a factor CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$expType <- factor(CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$expType, levels = unique(CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$expType)) # Checking the new dataypes and factor levels CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata %>% select( RawData, compName, compConcentration, expType) %>% map(class) ## $RawData ## [1] "numeric" ## ## $compName ## [1] "factor" ## ## $compConcentration ## [1] "numeric" ## ## $expType ## [1] "factor" # check levels of "compName" and "expType" CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata %>% select( compName, expType) %>% map(levels) ## $compName ## [1] "2,6-diisopropylnaphthalene" "decane" ## [3] "naphthalene" "Ethanol" ## [5] "S-medium" ## ## $expType ## [1] "experiment" "controlPositive" "controlNegative" "controlVehicleA" Scatterplot # plot dataset in a scatterplot scatterplot <- CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata %>% ggplot(aes(x = log10(compConcentration + .001), y = RawData))+ geom_point(aes(color = compName, shape = expType), size = 1.5, alpha = 0.8, position = position_jitter(width = 0.1))+ # jitter to avoid overlap labs( title = "Scatterplot CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata", x = "log10(compConcentration) in nM", y = "RawData in counts" ) scatterplot ## Warning: Removed 5 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`). The positive control for this experiments is controlPositive The negative control for this experiment is controlNegative. Organise Data: Gather data on offspring count for different concentrations of each compound. Statistical Analysis: Use statistical methods to determine if there’s a significant difference in offspring count between concentrations for each compound. Curve Fitting: Fit a curve to the data for each compound to find the concentration at which offspring count is halved (IC50). Compare Curves: Compare IC50 values between compounds to see if they differ. Normalising dataset # filter on "controlNegative" data CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_contNeg <- CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata %>% filter(expType == "controlNegative") # calculate mean of "RawData" of the filtered dataset contNeg_mean <- mean(CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_contNeg$RawData) # check contNeg_mean contNeg_mean ## [1] 85.9 # create a normalised column with the normalised values. CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata_norm <- CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata %>% mutate(normalised = RawData/mean(contNeg_mean)) # mean RawData mean(CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata_norm$RawData, na.rm=T) ## [1] 68.10423 # check normalised column CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata_norm %>% select(compName, expType, compConcentration, RawData, normalised) %>% reactable(defaultPageSize = 5) # check the normalisation values are a fraction of 1 CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_contNeg_norm <- CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata_norm %>% filter(expType == "controlNegative") contNegNorm_mean <- mean(CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_contNeg_norm$normalised) # check if mean value of controlNegative is equal to "1" contNegNorm_mean ## [1] 1 Scatterplot normalised dataset scatterplot_normalised <- CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata_norm %>% ggplot(aes(x = log10(compConcentration + .001), y = normalised))+ geom_point(aes(color = compName, shape = expType), size = 1.5, alpha = 0.8, position = position_jitter(width = 0.1))+ # jitter to avoid overlap labs( title = "Scatterplot normalised CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata", caption = "Dataset is normalised with the negative control mean", y = "Normalised RawData counts", x = "log10(compConcentration) in nM") scatterplot_normalised ## Warning: Removed 5 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`). Figure 1: Fig. 5.1: In this experiment, we have two control groups: the positive control, labeled as ‘controlPositive,’ and the negative control, labeled as ’controlNegative.
